item.title: This eufy C10 Self-Emptying Robot Vacuum Drops Over 50%, Practically Free Compared to Dyson
item.content:encoded:
Being and adult can be a lot. We’re expected to work at least eight hours a day — usually more. For some of us it might take over and hour to commute to work, each way. When we finally get home, we have dinners to cook and dirty clothes to launder. To stay healthy, we should be getting in some daily exercised too. Plus, some of us have small humans to take care of, pick up from school, help with their homework — it’s never ending. If you fall behind on vacuuming your living room, that’s completely understandable with everything else going on. Though, you work so hard, you deserve to come home to a clean home every day. That’s why you got to jump on this Amazon limited time deal for a Eufy robot vacuum.

The Eufy C10 can be scheduled to clean up for you every day while you’re out so you can come home to a clean living space. The robot vac is currently 54% off, saving your more than half. It normally is listed at $480, but the discount brings it down to just $220. That’s a savings of $260 for a limited time.

See at Amazon

Self-Empty Station

Not only does this vacuum clean your floors for you. It can also empty itself all by itself. The docking station it returns to after every trip has a three-liter dust bag which the robot vacuum empties into each day. So instead of needing to empty the robot vacuum every few days, you only need to empty the dust bag about every 60 days.

This robot vacuum has a powerful suction with 4,000 Pa of sucking power. The rolling brush makes it so the vac can pick up all kinds of tough debris like pet hair, dirt, and crumbs embedded deep in your carpet.

The vacuum is designed to be a short 2.85 inches tall. This slim shape allows it to navigate under tight, hard-to-reach spaces like beneath a couch, bed, or desk.

Navigating your home comes easy to this robot vacuum. The Eufy C10 uses laser navigation to map out the layout of your home, analyzing and creating an optimal path to take for a thorough cleaning.

You can used the companion app to mark off any no-go zones you don’t want it to enter. The app also can be used for scheduling when you want the robot vacuum to run. You even use voice controls to get it started on the fly.

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/this-eufy-c10-self-emptying-robot-vacuum-drops-over-50-practically-free-compared-to-dyson-2000638356

item.title: A Duck With A Gun Has Replaced Battlefield 6 In The Top 5 Most-Played Steam Games
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever gone duck hunting? It’s terrifying. Somehow those birds are always watching, ready, hiding just out of plain sight ready to get you. Mmm. On second thought I might have that experience confused with something else. Regardless, murderous animals are funny and horrifying, and it seems a lot of folks on Steam are in agreement as duck-based indie shooter Escape From Duckov has just pulled ahead of EA’s big AAA shooter Battlefield 6 in concurrent players.

Read More: There’s A Damned Good Reason Escape From Duckov Has Sold A Million Copies In A Week

Released on October 16, 2025, Escape From Duckov is a solo survival extraction shooter featuring ducks with guns who aren’t afraid to use them. It has that lovely charm that many indie games tend to get when they fuse an otherwise serious, well-executed genre with a not-so-serious premise: in this case, ducks with guns. And it would seem (h/t Dexerto) that us extraction diehards or those who just enjoy silliness aren’t the only ones drawn to these funny birds; the game has recently outstripped Battlefield 6 in concurrent players, successfully hopping over the popular milsim shooter in the top five most-played games on Steam at the time of this writing.

Read More: Arc Raiders Is So Good I’m Worried It Will Completely Take Over My Life

Humor aside, it’s a well-earned accomplishment as Duckov is by all accounts a very good game. Battlefield 6 does have a new season coming up in a few days, so Duckov’s lead may not last, but hey, for us extraction dorks, it’s a nice thing to see. And, hey, maybe the broader gaming community is warming up to extraction shooters a bit more? I’d be totally here for that ahead of Arc Raiders’ launch next week.



https://kotaku.com/escape-from-duckov-battlefield-6-bf6-steam-extraction-2000638836

item.title: This Is The Closest We’ve Gotten To A New KPop Demon Hunters Song
item.content:encoded:
The KPop Demon Hunters soundtrack is going to dominate people’s year-end streaming roundups, and fans are hungry for more songs from its girl group. While there was a moment where we thought we might have gotten a new Huntr/x banger that turned out to be a Spotify hack, Netflix hasn’t put out any new music from the fictional K-pop group yet. What’s a Huntr/x fan to do other than listen to the soundtrack on loop? Well, Ejae, the singing voice of lead vocalist Rumi, has finally put out her own debut single, and yeah, the girl can sing even when she’s not slaying demons.

“In Another World” is a ballad that sounds like something you’d hear over a Disney musical’s end credits. It’s definitely giving the late 2000s/early 2010s adult contemporary diva, along the lines of Leona Lewis and Adele, so don’t come expecting a Huntr/x-style banger here. All that said, the song is a vocal showcase for Ejae, who soars over its chorus as she sings of an estranged relationship that’s fallen through. Check it out here:

Ejae’s career trajectory has been inspiring to watch unfold as KPop Demon Hunters’ success has put her in the spotlight. She began training to be a K-pop idol at a young age in 2003, although she wasn’t approved for a debut for over a decade. Ultimately, she discontinued her idol training to pursue a career as a songwriter. After working with groups like Red Velvet and  Le Sserafim, she was brought onto KPop Demon Hunters to write songs and record demos, then was asked to be Rumi’s singing voice in the final film. And now, she’s got some of the biggest songs of 2025 and is becoming a household name and performing on late-night talk shows. Add her to the list of later-in-life success stories that teach us to never give up on our dreams.



https://kotaku.com/kpop-demon-hunters-new-song-ejae-in-another-world-video-2000638832

item.title: HP 17.3″ Ryzen 5 Laptop Bundle Goes for Peanuts With 75% Off and $200 Worth of Free Accessories
item.content:encoded:
Upgrading to a new business laptop shouldn’t mean breaking the bank, but it also doesn’t mean settling for something basic just to save money. Ideally, your work laptop should be powerful enough to handle your busiest days, plus support some weekend fun like gaming or streaming without slowing down.

HP offers some of the best options on the market for this, though the performance usually comes with a higher price tag. Thankfully, that changes today. Amazon is currently offering a mind-boggling 75% discount on the 17.3-inch HP touchscreen laptop, bringing the price down to just $750. Honestly, that’s what you’d pay for most entry-level machines on a normal day, and the offer doesn’t end here. You’re also getting a free accessory kit worth almost $200 with your purchase. The only catch? The discount ends soon, meaning you don’t have a lot of time left to grab it. Snag it for less while the offer is still available.

See at Amazon

A Powerful Processor for Impressive Multitasking

Starting with the performance, you’re getting an AMD Ryzen 5 7430U processor that’s made to support heavier applications and creative tasks without lags. Along with that, there’s 32GB of RAM to take care of multitasking. Whether your day requires you to hop between multiple programs at once, use a ton of different tabs simultaneously, or test your sanity with longer, never-ending spreadsheets, it’s all going to be possible. Storage-wise, you’re covered with a 1TB SSD that’s spacious enough to house all your essentials, plus also ensures faster boot times.

The large 17.3-inch display is much bigger than most other options in this range, and gives you plenty of screen real estate for work and play. Visuals stay lifelike in all lighting conditions, thanks to its anti-glare coating. You’ve also got a full-sized keyboard that’s quite comfortable to use – you won’t be left with a sore wrist at the end of a long work day.

This machine runs on Windows 11 Pro, which comes pre-installed. The operating system is one of the most user-friendly ones out there, and Copilot integration takes the experience even further. You’re going to have an AI assistant ready to help you 24/7. Need help with a math problem? Ask away. Figuring out how long to bake that cake? It’s got you covered. Other freebies include a wireless mouse, a USB hub, a 128GB USB flash drive, and a 7-in-1 cleaning kit.

See at Amazon



https://kotaku.com/hp-17-3%e2%80%b3-ryzen-5-laptop-bundle-goes-for-peanuts-with-75-off-and-200-worth-of-free-accessories-2000637760

item.title: Microsoft Gaming Boss Phil Spencer Reveals His Thoughts On Xbox Using AI
item.content:encoded:
The AI arms race is currently eating up hundreds of billions of dollars in investment as companies compete over a technology whose exact benefits are still far from clear. Microsoft is at the center of that fight. How is the head of Microsoft gaming thinking about fitting AI into development? “Our AI use today is much more operational than it is in the creative space,” Phil Spencer said during a recent panel discussion.

As reported by IGN, he was speaking at the Paley International Council Summit in Palo Alto, California on the topic of “Big Ideas, Small Games: Creativity Beyond the Blockbuster” with Double Fine studio head Tim Schafer following the release of Keeper. Microsoft has been pushing AI into all of its products and CEO Satya Nadella has bragged about relying on multiple AI assistants throughout the day to run one of the biggest tech firms in the world.

But it’s less clear how those tools are being used by rank-and-file employees within the company, especially on the gaming side. According to Spencer, Microsoft gaming’s biggest deployment of AI technology right now is in its platform moderation tools. The company announced last year that it’s been using AI tools to help flag and intercept offensive or spam-related communications on Xbox.

“So we have AI that we use to make sure that the conversation and topics that are happening, and for protected child accounts and other things and who gets to talk to those accounts to those people, is locked down by parents or guardians who are setting those controls,” he said during yesterday’s panel. “That’s our primary use of AI inside of our organization today, which maybe isn’t the most glamorous use of AI, but it’s something that I fundamentally believe in.”

When it comes to other applications on the player-facing front, Spencer suggested AI could also help with one of the biggest challenges in gaming right now: game discovery and curation. “It’s not in practice today, but is there a way for us to use discovery based on things that you’ve done in the past to surface the next thing that you might not know about that might be interesting to you?” he speculated.

When it comes to game development, however, Spencer seemed to downplay any significant use of AI tools when it comes to things like creating concept art, programming code, or scripting dialogue. “On the creative side, I really leave it up to the teams,” the executive said. “I have found that creative teams will use tools that make their job easier when it makes their job easier, and any top-down mandate that ‘Thou must use a certain tool’…is not really a path to success. I look at the teams, and we make tools available, and I kind of let it organically percolate.”

He continued,

On the production side, which I think is where a lot of people go…we don’t have any goals in our model for that to happen. I think more about the pace of creativity, maybe the number of things we can try and take risks on before we decide on our next opportunity. But our AI use today is much more operational than it is in the creative space.

That’s a far cry from the promises that some gaming company executives are making about how AI can help them drastically cut costs and ship games more quickly and efficiently. Last year, EA CEO Andrew Wilson said AI was at “the very core” of the Madden and Battlefield publisher’s business. That company is now reportedly banking on an AI revolution to help it service a new $20 billion loan as part of a private equity buyout led by Saudi Arabia.



https://kotaku.com/microsoft-xbox-ai-development-moderation-phil-spencer-2000638826
